case_info.title: Wrongful Dismissal - Sarah Chen vs TechCorp Solutions
case_info.summary: Sarah Chen, a Senior Safety Engineer with nearly two years of service at TechCorp Solutions Ltd., alleges wrongful dismissal following her submission of a comprehensive safety violation report. On 8 December 2023, during a routine facility inspection, Ms. Chen identified critical safety violations in the company's chemical storage area, including inadequate ventilation systems providing only 2 air changes per hour (well below the required 6), inoperative exhaust fans, improper storage of incompatible chemicals, blocked emergency equipment, and insufficient personal protective equipment for employees. She documented these violations in a detailed report submitted on 10 December 2023, citing specific breaches of HSE COSHH Regulations 2002, HSE Workplace Regulations 1992, and Management of Health and Safety at Work Regulations 1999. The report estimated remediation costs of £35,000-£50,000 and warned of potential HSE fines up to £20,000 per violation, employee illness risks, and possible criminal liability. Exactly 33 days later, on 12 January 2024, Ms. Chen was dismissed via email with immediate effect, citing 'ongoing budget constraints and organisational restructuring' as the reason. Ms. Chen alleges this dismissal constitutes victimisation for her protected safety disclosure and seeks reinstatement to her position, compensation for lost earnings, and damages for injury to feelings. She contends the timing of her dismissal so soon after her safety report demonstrates a causal connection and retaliatory motive. TechCorp maintains the dismissal was part of a legitimate cost-reduction initiative affecting multiple departments and denies any connection to the safety report, claiming the restructuring decision predated Ms. Chen's report and was driven by genuine business needs.

top_relevant.title: Employment Law Precedents
top_relevant.description: Under Employment Rights Act 1996, employees with 2+ years' service are protected from unfair dismissal. Dismissal must be for a fair reason and follow a fair procedure.

applicable_rules.description: If contract terms are clear and violated, assess whether breach is material
applicable_rules.legal_basis: Sale of Goods Act 1979, Contract law principles

applicable_rules.description: If contract language is ambiguous, apply standard interpretation rules
applicable_rules.legal_basis: Parol evidence rule, contra proferentem doctrine

monetary_assessment.description: Moderate damages for material breaches with some complications

escalation_path.description: Formal demand for performance or damages
Attempt mediated resolution
Binding arbitration if contractually required
Issue proceedings in County Court or High Court
Appeal to Court of Appeal if permission granted
